abstract.p: James E McWilliams letter comments on September 24 Week in Review article on academic wrangling over Constitutional right to bear arms

block.p: The academic wrangling over the founders' intentions with respect to individual gun ownership overlooks an important parallel (Week in Review, Sept. 24). Similar scrutiny of their intentions with respect to slavery confirms a tacit endorsement of the right to own chattel. Yet legislators expunged that right when its moral repugnance (and decreasing economic utility) caused widespread public concern.

The academic wrangling over the founders' intentions with respect to individual gun ownership overlooks an important parallel (Week in Review, Sept. 24). Similar scrutiny of their intentions with respect to slavery confirms a tacit endorsement of the right to own chattel. Yet legislators expunged that right when its moral repugnance (and decreasing economic utility) caused widespread public concern.

By approaching the founders' intentions in a fundamentalist way, scholars ahistorically play down the evolving values that the United States Constitution has proved so capable of accommodating. They should be exploring channels to modify what may in fact be a constitutional right to bear arms.

In an era when children have legitimate worries about getting shot at school, we would do better to assume that the founders did indeed stipulate the right to gun ownership and then figure out a way to reverse it.
JAMES E. MC WILLIAMS Austin, Tex., Sept. 24, 2000
